author: shirima wanja jane
text: Lastly, I want to thank the people of Kilifi County, Kilifi Health department, and more specifically the AGYW who allowed us into their lives and experiences. Asanteni Sana.

author: shirima wanja jane
text:
The lessons are so many.  You can read more about the findings of the research project at the @aphrc website. Here is the link.

https://t.co/8EZwB35RXr

author: shirima wanja jane
text: The link between SGBV, unintended pregnancies and unsafe abortion cannot be ignored. There is a need for Survivors of SGBV to get timely access to justice, unfortunately this is only a distant dream to many survivors I encountered.

author: shirima wanja jane
text: Intersectionality. Policy makers and all stakeholders need to recognize the intersectionality among AGYW. Not all AGYW experiences are the same, intervention programs should be tailor made to address these intersectionalities.

author: shirima wanja jane
text: There is an urgent need for comprehensive sex education. The lack of correct information in SRH  matters among AGYW is wanting.Information is power and with proper Sex Ed, AGYW stand a better chance of making informed decisions, reduce unintended pregnancies and unsafe abortion.

author: shirima wanja jane
text: Here are a few lessons I picked from the experience as a  research assistant. Seeing first hand how AGYW have challenges in accessing SRH services. There is an urgent need for breaking the barriers to access of SRH services including access to safe abortion. https://t.co/QUBgMn0I3m

author: shirima wanja jane
text: The research project aimed at exploring women and adolescent girls’ experiences towards unintended pregnancies and the way they navigate abortion decision making, in order to better understand the barriers and opportunities to access safe abortion advice, products, and care. https://t.co/yNBTTOlqVt

author: shirima wanja jane
text: Today we had a closing event of the She Makes Her Safe Choice Programme and I'm super grateful I got a chance to be part of this program.Thanks to @aphrc, @Rutgers_INTL and all other partners. Doing Ethnographic Research in Kilifi cemented my resolve for advocating for SRHR.

author: shirima wanja jane
text: The Sleep Diagnostic and Treatment Centre (SDTC) Nairobi. https://t.co/nNqYhgudbr

author: shirima wanja jane
text:
Be consistent. Go to bed at the same time each night and get up at the same time each morning.
 A peaceful bedtime routine sends a powerful signal to your brain that it’s time to wind down and let go of the day’s stresses. https://t.co/Ny7RN36sY9

author: shirima wanja jane
text: Sleep and mental health are closely connected. Sleep deprivation affects your psychological state and mental health. Those with mental health problems are more likely to have sleep disorders such as insomnia. https://t.co/YnIIKy2TQw

author: shirima wanja jane
text: Lifestyle choices such as keeping the brain stimulated until late in the evening, such as by working late, playing video games, or using other electronic devices trigger poor sleeping habits. https://t.co/Ehbht5MF5c
